Magnesium therapy is recommended for people with ventricular arrhythmia associated with torsades de pointes who present with long QT syndrome, and for the treatment of people with digoxin intoxication-induced arrhythmias. There is no evidence that omega-3 fatty acid supplementation is beneficial. A 2022 review found that some dietary supplements, including micronutrients, may reduce risk factors for cardiovascular disease.

== Management == Cardiovascular disease is treatable with initial treatment primarily focused on diet and lifestyle interventions. Influenza may make heart attacks and strokes more likely and therefore influenza vaccination may decrease the chance of cardiovascular events and death in people with heart disease. Proper CVD management necessitates a focus on MI and stroke cases due to their combined high mortality rate, keeping in mind the cost-effectiveness of any intervention, especially in developing countries with low or middle-income levels. Regarding MI, strategies using aspirin, atenolol, streptokinase or tissue plasminogen activator have been compared for quality-adjusted life-year (QALY) in regions of low and middle income. The costs for a single QALY for aspirin and atenolol were less than US$25, streptokinase was about $680, and t-PA was $16,000.

Aspirin, ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, and statins used together for secondary CVD prevention in the same regions showed single QALY costs of $350. There are also surgical or procedural interventions that can save someone's life or prolong it. For heart valve problems, a person could have surgery to replace the valve. For arrhythmias, a pacemaker can be put in place to help reduce abnormal heart rhythms and for a heart attack, there are multiple options two of these are a coronary angioplasty and a coronary artery bypass surgery. There is probably no additional benefit in terms of mortality and serious adverse events when blood pressure targets were lowered to ≤ 135/85 mmHg from ≤ 140 to 160/90 to 100 mmHg.

== Epidemiology == Cardiovascular diseases are the leading cause of death worldwide and in all regions except Africa. In 2008, 30% of all global death was attributed to cardiovascular diseases. Death caused by cardiovascular diseases are also higher in low- and middle-income countries as over 80% of all global deaths caused by cardiovascular diseases occurred in those countries. It is also estimated that by 2030, over 23 million people will die from cardiovascular diseases each year. It is estimated that 60% of the world's cardiovascular disease burden will occur in the South Asian subcontinent despite only accounting for 20% of the world's population. This may be secondary to a combination of genetic predisposition and environmental factors. Organizations such as the Indian Heart Association are working with the World Heart Federation to raise awareness about this issue.

== Research == There is evidence that cardiovascular disease existed in pre-history, and research into cardiovascular disease dates from at least the 18th century. The causes, prevention, and/or treatment of all forms of cardiovascular disease remain active fields of biomedical research, with hundreds of scientific studies being published on a weekly basis. Recent areas of research include the link between inflammation and atherosclerosis the potential for novel therapeutic interventions, and the genetics of coronary heart disease.

items.question: What did the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) determine in 2015 regarding partially hydrogenated oils (PHOs)?
items.answer: In 2015, the FDA determined that there was 'no longer a consensus among qualified experts that partially hydrogenated oils (PHOs), which are the primary dietary source of industrially produced trans fatty acids (IP-TFA), are generally recognized as safe (GRAS) for any use in human food'.

items.question: How has traditional screening for primary prevention interventions typically categorized individuals for treatment?
items.answer: Traditional screening has used absolute risk scores, such as Framingham or Reynolds risk scores, to stratify people. This process separates individuals who receive lifestyle interventions (generally those at lower and intermediate risk) from those who receive medication (those at higher risk).

items.question: What are the primary risk factors for cardiovascular disease, and what is the estimated percentage of CVD deaths attributed to some of the most significant ones?
items.answer: The main risk factors for cardiovascular disease include high blood pressure, smoking, diabetes mellitus, lack of exercise, obesity, high blood cholesterol, poor diet, and excessive alcohol consumption. Of these, high blood pressure is estimated to account for approximately 13% of CVD deaths, tobacco for 9%, diabetes for 6%, lack of exercise for 6%, and obesity for 5%.

items.question: What is the relationship between the risk factor of hypertension and a specific type of cardiovascular disease?
items.answer: Hypertension, or raised blood pressure, is identified as a modifiable risk factor for heart diseases. This risk factor is directly linked to a specific condition called hypertensive heart disease, which is defined as a disease of the heart that is secondary to high blood pressure.

items.question: What are three significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease, and how does each one contribute to an individual's likelihood of developing the condition?
items.answer: Three significant risk factors for cardiovascular disease are genetics, age, and sex. Genetics plays an important role, as a person's risk increases by approximately 3-fold if their parents have cardiovascular disease. Age is considered the most important risk factor, with the risk tripling with each decade of life, partly due to increased cholesterol levels and loss of arterial elasticity. Sex is also a factor, with men being about 50% more likely to develop CVD and being diagnosed 7 to 10 years earlier than women. For coronary heart disease specifically, middle-aged men are 2 to 5 times more likely to be affected than women.

items.question: Describe the global mortality trends for cardiovascular disease, including the total number of deaths in 2015, the primary types of CVD responsible for these deaths, and the differing trends observed in developed versus developing countries.
items.answer: Cardiovascular diseases (CVD) resulted in 17.9 million deaths globally in 2015. The two primary types responsible for these fatalities are coronary artery disease and stroke, which together account for 80% of CVD deaths in males and 75% in females. There is a significant difference in mortality trends based on economic development; death rates from CVD have been increasing in much of the developing world, while they have been declining in most of the developed world since the 1970s.

items.question: What are some specific examples of inflammatory heart diseases, and what parts of the heart do they affect?
items.answer: Examples of inflammatory heart diseases include Endocarditis, which is an inflammation of the heart's inner layer (the endocardium) and most commonly affects the heart valves. Another is Myocarditis, an inflammation of the myocardium, the muscular part of the heart, which is frequently caused by viral infections. A specific type of this is Eosinophilic myocarditis, also an inflammation of the myocardium, but caused by activated eosinophilic white blood cells.

items.question: What are the observed sex-based differences in cardiovascular disease risk, and what is a proposed biological explanation for these differences?
items.answer: Men are about 50% more likely to develop cardiovascular disease (CVD) and are typically diagnosed seven to ten years earlier than women. Coronary heart diseases are also two to five times more common in middle-aged men. A proposed explanation for these differences is hormonal variation. In women, the predominant sex hormone, estrogen, may have protective effects on glucose metabolism, the hemostatic system, and endothelial cell function. After menopause, estrogen production decreases, which can lead to a more atherogenic lipid profile in women, thus increasing their risk.

items.question: What dietary components are associated with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease, and what dietary patterns or food types are recommended for prevention?
items.answer: A higher risk of cardiovascular disease is linked to high dietary intakes of saturated fat, trans-fats, salt, sugar, and processed meats. Conversely, a lower risk is associated with diets high in fruits, vegetables, and fiber. Beneficial dietary patterns for prevention include healthy plant-based diets, the Mediterranean diet, and the DASH diet. There is also a consensus that replacing saturated fat with unsaturated fat is beneficial for reducing cardiovascular risk.
